CORE.name: Black Hole
CORE.definition: A region in spacetime exhibiting such strong gravitational effects that nothing—not even particles and electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from inside it.

chain: Analysis of orbital motion of stars around a supermassive compact object
GROUNDING.evidence_summary: Black holes are indirectly observed through their gravitational effects on surrounding matter and light. Strong evidence comes from observations of stars orbiting seemingly empty space at very high speeds, as well as the detection of gravitational waves from black hole mergers. The Event Horizon Telescope has directly imaged the shadow of a black hole.

components.name: Matter
components.ref: Unknown; all matter is crushed into an infinitely small point.

requires: Sufficient mass concentrated in a small enough space

relational: Accretion of matter from surrounding environment

lifecycle: Formation from stellar collapse or primordial density fluctuations
Evaporation through Hawking radiation (extremely slow for stellar mass black holes)
